moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. d4 Bd7: Routine play up until now. The game gets interesting here.
moves.5... f6: This move weakens the K-side, where Pillsbury intends to castle.
moves.6. c3 Nge7: Blacks position is exteremely cramped. Young initiates a vigourous attack to exploit this.
moves.7. Nh4: Clearing the way for the KB pawn to become a battering ram.
moves.7... g6: Yet another K-side weakness, but how else is he to move his Bishop to clear the way for castling?
moves.8... Bg7 9. f5: Whether Black or White initiates the exchange, Black's K-side will be ripped open. The best move may well be 9... P-N4, driving the Knight and locking the Pawn formation.
moves.9... gxf5 10. exf5: With the exposed K-side, Pillsbury's King may be best off in the center or even, if he can clear his Q, on the Q-side with an eventual ...O-O-O.
moves.11. Qg4: Immediately intiating an attack along the open line.
moves.12. Rf3: Bringing another big gun into the attack. Because of his cramped position, Pillsbury cannot bring forces over for defense.
moves.12... Rg8: This attempt at defense falls a day late and a dollar short.
moves.13. Rh3: Aiming ominously at Black's trapped King.
moves.13... Bh6: Merely driving the Queen to a better attacking position.
moves.14. Qh5: Creating a fearsome battery on the KR file.
moves.14... Bxc1: As good or bad as anything else. Pillsbury has no good options left.
moves.15... Kg7: With the Pawn pinned, this move is forced.

players: Franklin K. Young  vs. Harry N. Pillsbury
opening: Ruy Lopez (C62), old Steinitz defence, Nimzovich attack
